awd_titl_txt: Numerical and Analytical Investigations on Nonlocal Dispersive Wave Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Nonlocal dispersive wave equations have been recently applied in many areas such as electromagnetism, acoustics, cosmology, elasticity, biology, hydrodynamics, viscoelasticity, seismics, water wave, plasma, quantum mechanics, brain and consciousness, and so on. However, their nonlocality introduces considerable challenges in both mathematical analysis and numerical simulations. This project seeks to address fundamental issues related to mathematical modeling and numerical simulations of nonlocal dispersive wave equations as well as their solution properties. The proposed project will bridge the gap between different areas, enhance interdisciplinary research, and advance the application of fractional differential equations in practice. Since nonlocal wave equations have broad applications in physics, chemistry, biology and engineering, the research in this project has great potentials to advance the research and technology in relevant areas.

The main objectives of this research are to build mathematical and numerical treatments for the nonlocal Schroedinger wave equations, and to provide a deeper understanding of the modeling with long-range interactions, so as to advance their application to problems with nonlocality. In this project, both the discrete nonlinear Schroedinger (DNLS) equation with long-range interactions and the fractional nonlinear Schroedinger (fNLS) equation with the fractional Laplacian will be investigated. Integrating the discrete and continuous models offers a new opportunity for a deeper understanding of the nonlocality of the Schroedinger wave equations. On the one hand, accurate algorithms will be developed to improve the efficiency and reduce the computational costs in simulating the DNLS with large lattice sites, especially in two- or three-dimensional lattices. On the other hand, efficient and accurate numerical methods for discretizing the fractional Laplacian will be designed and applied to study the properties of the stationary states and dynamics of fNLS. The study on the DNLS and fNLS will provide a deeper understanding on modeling and properties of long-range interactions, as well as is benefitting the development of numerical algorithms for fractional differential equations.

por.por_cntn:
Recently, there has been a rapid growing trend of research on nonlocal wave equations. The application of nonlocal wave equations is widespread and includes areas such as electromagnetism, acoustics, cosmology, elasticity, biology, hydrodynamics, viscoelasticity, seismics, water wave, plasma, quantum mechanics, brain and consciousness, and so on. A principal appealing feature of the nonlocal wave equations is their nonlocality, which offers the ability to integrate different scales in a single model. This feature makes the nonlocal wave equations an attractive model for studying complex phenomena. However, its nonlocality also introduces significant theoretical and numerical challenges. So far, understanding of the nonlocal wave equations remains limited.

This project addresses fundamental issues related to mathematical modeling and numerical simulations of nonlocal dispersive wave equations as well as the properties of their solutions. The main objectives of this research are to build mathematical and numerical treatments for the nonlocal Schrodinger wave equations, and to provide a deeper understanding of the modeling with long-range interactions, so as to advance their application to problems with nonlocality.

We investigated both the discrete nonlinear Schrodinger equation with long-range interactions and its continuous counterpart with the fractional Laplacian. Computationally, finite difference methods were developed for both the fractional Laplacian and its variations. These methods are the first finite difference methods for high-dimensional fractional Laplacians. Moreover, our numerical analysis provides the strict conditions for both consistency and optimal accuracy, advancing the fundamental knowledge of nonlocal operators. To facilitate the applications, fast algorithms were developed to reduce both computational and storage costs. We studied the nonlocal effects and solution properties of the nonlinear dispersive equations. Our results show that the well-known recurrence of plane waves cannot be observed in the fractional cases, and moreover the dynamics of the fractional nonlinear Schrodinger equation is more chaotic than that of its standard counterpart. Integrating the discrete and continuous models offers us a new opportunity for a deeper understanding of the nonlocality of the dispersive wave equations. 

Our results enhance the understanding of nonlocal dispersive wave equations and promote their applications in other fields. Accurate algorithms developed in this project improve the efficiency and reduce the computational costs in simulating the nonlocal problems, especially in two- or three-dimensions. The numerical methods and analysis developed in this project provide the state-of-the-art results for the fractional Laplacian. It promotes a deeper understanding of modeling and applications with fractional differential equations. Our results on plane wave and soliton dynamics fill the gaps in the study of wave equations and advance the understanding the fractional quantum mechanics. This project enhances interdisciplinary research by bridging the gap between different research areas, and advances the application of nonlocal models in practice. The state-of-the-art numerical methods that developed in this project have been applied to other fields, including physics, geosciences, and material sciences. This project also integrates with teaching, training and learning at Missouri University of Science and Technology through a new interdisciplinary seminar series for undergraduate and graduate students  and through the development of an enhanced numerical course for undergraduate and graduate students. 

This research project results in nine journal papers (seven published in refereed journals, two manuscripts submitted).  The results of this project have been presented in twenty-four conference and colloquium presentations. This award (partially) supported four PhD students, including the first PhD student of the new computational and applied mathematics program at the department of mathematic and statistics, Missouri University of Science and Technology. Two of them have graduated with the partial support of this project. The support from NSF has enhanced the new PhD program and encouraged more students to pursue their degree in computational and applied mathematics.
